title: Set Operations
description:
Practice using sets for common data analysis tasks.

## Requirements

1. Define `find_common(list1, list2)` that returns a set of elements common to both lists
2. Define `find_unique_to_first(list1, list2)` that returns a set of elements in list1 but not in list2
3. Define `count_unique(items)` that returns the count of unique elements in a list

## Example Usage

```python
find_common([1, 2, 3], [2, 3, 4])         # Returns {2, 3}
find_unique_to_first([1, 2, 3], [2, 3, 4]) # Returns {1}
count_unique([1, 2, 2, 3, 1, 4])           # Returns 4
```

# Test your functions
list_a = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
list_b = [4, 5, 6, 7, 8]

print(f"Common elements: {find_common(list_a, list_b)}")
print(f"Unique to first: {find_unique_to_first(list_a, list_b)}")
print(f"Unique count in [1, 2, 2, 3, 1, 4]: {count_unique([1, 2, 2, 3, 1, 4])}")
hints: Convert lists to sets to use set operations
Use set intersection (&) or .intersection() for common elements
Use set difference (-) or .difference() for unique to first
Use len(set(items)) to count unique elements
